bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, December 27, 1902

div1.p: Kean discusses a strategy to lobby Congress to approve a pension for Emilie Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, December 27, 1902
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A, KELLY
WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon General's Office,
WASHINGTON.
December 27, 1902.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
A movement is on foot among the friends
of the late Dr. Walter Reed to get for his
wife a pension which is in some way commensu-
rate with the service which Dr. Reed has ren-
dered the country. A special bill will be
introduced by Senator Thos. S. Martin of Vir-
ginia on the 5th of January for this purpose.
We think that a pension of $200.00 a month
should be asked for so that a little trimming
may be done in Committee without making it
entirely inadequate.

Will you take up this matter with some
Senator of your acquaintance, stating in a few
words the character of Dr. Reed's service and
his standing as a scientist, for you will find
that most Congressmen are entirely unfamiliar
with both. It is very important that members
of the Pension Committee should be approached
on the subject, and if you do not know a mem-
ber of that Committee it is suggested that you
ask the Senator to whom you write to see a
member of the Committee in the matter.

This being the short session it was not
intended to take the matter up this year, but
Senator Martin believes that it can be pushed
through, and advises that it be done at once.
Prompt action is therefore necessary.

It is thought best that the Surgeon Gen-
eral's Office should not take an active part
in its official capacity, and my action is
therefore taken purely in a personal capacity
as a warm friend of Dr. Reed and his family
and not as Assistant to the Surgeon General:
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, J.R. Kean
Major, Surg. USA.
